SB 828 had a great coalition behind it but special thanks to the bill‚Äôs sponsors @BayAreaCouncil & @SVLeadershipGrp, which worked so hard to craft & advance it & get it signed into law.

Lots of work remains - I‚Äôm excited for what my colleagues & I have in store for 2023! - but we‚Äôve made steady progress toward a better approach to housing: One that recognizes that a top goal must be having enough homes for everyone who needs them.

And if they don‚Äôt do this planning & rezoning timely & correctly - or if they try to game the system - there are big consequences due to other laws the Legislature has passed. https://t.co/F4hvVXqMJJ

As a result, cities that used to game the system & blow off state housing law no longer can. Cities that bragged about meeting super low housing goals now have to plan & zone for dramatically more homes - numbers that actually match our housing needs.

These higher RHNA numbers mean cities must plan for much more housing in their housing element + zone for it.

So Cal & Bay Area‚Äôs regional numbers tripled.

SF‚Äôs # went from ~28k to ~82k. Beverly Hills went from 3 (yes, 3) to ~3k.

Plus we tightened enforcement & accountability.

SB 828 revamped how CA sets state mandated housing allocations (RHNA), thus increasing those housing numbers dramatically. That‚Äôs why cities are seeing much higher RHNA numbers for the 8 yr housing cycle we‚Äôre entering.

Before SB 828, cities‚Äô housing goals were way low. No more.

On housing policy, I‚Äôm perhaps best known for my work on zoning (eg SB 827, 50, 10, 478) & streamlining (SB 35, 886)

But those aren‚Äôt the most impactful bills I‚Äôve authored.

In 2018, I authored a law that went under the radar but is now hugely impacting housing in CA: SB 828.üßµ

New York opened 2 safe consumption sites this year.

https://t.co/xwWxpZHn1z

We have the tools to reverse overdoses. To allow people to use drugs in a clean, indoor space rather than on the street ‚Äì with supervision from health care professionals & the opportunity to get connected to treatment.

In SF, almost 45% of overdose deaths happened when someone had both meth and fentanyl in their systems.

Bottom line: Our legislative leadership & Legislative Women‚Äôs Caucus worked very hard to establish - for the very first time - & independent entity to investigate claims of misconduct. After 3 years of operation, it‚Äôs time to evaluate how the WCU is doing & how it can do better.

It‚Äôs also time to allow our legislative staff to unionize. I supported past efforts to do so & I‚Äôll support current efforts. When I was a member of the Board of Supervisors, our staff were unionized & it caused no problems at all & allowed staff to speak with a unified voice.

We also need to take a hard look at our own laws. Several years ago, we ended the Legislature‚Äôs immunity from retaliation claims. That was progress, but we need to do more, including passing a new version of AB 2032 (2018) to allow public access to sustained misconduct complaints

The least we can do is ensure our staffers are safe at work & they can come forward & be confident their complaints will be fully & fairly investigated. It‚Äôs time for the Legislature to do a deep dive into how the WCU is functioning & how it is succeeding or failing our staff.
